Rwanda InstitutionalReformCredit - Release ofthe Third Tranche- FullCompliance (NO.3721-RW)
I.Background
1. The IRC was designed to support the Government o f Rwanda's reform effort in the implementation o f its PRSP. The main objectives o f the reform program are in line with the PRSP, to help focus the development agenda on poverty reduction, sustain economic growth in the range o f 6-7 percent and reduce the incidence o fpoverty from 60 percent in2000 to about 52 percent in 2004. The medium-term actions aim to (i) revitalize agriculture and the rural economy, (ii)strengthen the private sector; (iii) build human resources and (iv) improve governance and the effectiveness, efficiency and poverty impact o f public sector actions. These areas cover the six thematic priorities identified inthe PRSP.
2. The IRC builds on the progress made inreforms under the preceding Economic Recovery Credit (ERC) and consolidates the benefits from those reforms. The IRC focuses on: (i) improving public expenditure management building on an ongoing public expenditure management review, and a financial accountability review and action plan (FARAP); (ii) private sector development including privatization and the reform o fthe financial sector, buildingon the work done under the ERC to prepare enterprises for privatization, and working closely with the Competitiveness and Enterprise Development Project (CEDP) that i s providing technical assistance for the implementation o f reforms; and (iii) addressing gender and budget related institutional issues in the area o f human development. Reforms in agriculture and rural development and other institutional reforms in the social sectors were closely monitored under the IRC.
11. RecentEconomicDevelopments
3. Following the release o f the second (fixed) tranche o f the IRC, government continued its commitment to reform, with greater attention to measures to generate economic growth. GDP growth continues to be maintained at just under 3% per annum. This slow down has resulted from lower than expected agricultural output, and the current electricity shortage. The agriculture sector i s highly vulnerable to weather variations. Inaddition, the manufacturing sector has also been subject to the vagaries o f the weather, as a result o f the fall in electricity generation power that arose from low water levels following the recent drought. The associated electricity shortages have contributed to this development, and has impacted on the performance o f the textiles, cement, chemicals and beverages industries. Inflation has increased significantly since the final quarter o f 2002. Inflation excluding food prices has increased from 3.6 percent in March 2003 to 7.3 percent inMay 2004. Inthe case o f food price inflation, this has exceeded 13 percent since 2003 and i s now estimated at 17percent. Overall, total inflationwas at 7.7 percent at end o f 2003, and reached a high o f 12.4 percent by the end o f May 2004 before dropping to 12.3 percent at the endJune.  - L -
4. To address the issue of growth, government has outlined an agriculture development strategy, with emphasis on production for the market which the Bank will support through the Rural Support Credit. Inaddition, policy and institutional measures to support the soundness o f the financial sector (with an emphasis on micro-finance and financial intermediation), as well as improvements in the overall business environment are being supported under the upcoming Poverty Reduction Strategy Credit. Furthermore, an upcoming transport project, and urban infrastructure project, and an emergency project to address the shortages inthe energy sector will helpto reduce the hightransaction costs to doing business.
5. Public Finances and Expenditures. The government has made significant progress in improving the revenue base which i s now at 13.5 percent o f GDP (compared to the levels o f 12.2% o f GDP in 2002 and 11.4% o f GDP in 2001). Given that there has already been an increase inthe VAT to 18 percent (from 15 percent), and an improvement intax administration during 2002-03, any further significant improvements intax revenue will have to come from an increase in the tax base through a shift in economic activity from the informal to formal economy. To achieve this the government has begun the articulation o f an agriculture strategy to promote increased production for the market. In addition, the government continues to work toward passing the land law policy which will provide an additional source o f revenue, at the local level.
6. To achieve poverty reduction goals, government expenditure i s likely to increase in2005 relative to 2004. Government is considering increasing allocations to health, education, energy, water, roads, as well as transfers to local governments. New programs to establish an export promotion zone and plans to post-pone budget outlays for demobilizationto 2005 will all require increased expenditures. This implies that the government's domestic fiscal deficit which i s currently at 7.8 percent o f GDP (relative to a level o f 4.2 percent) in 2005 will remain 7.8 percent, at the minimum, and i s likelyto increase.
7. Given the above context, the government plans to base extemal financing on a combination o f extemal grant and loan resources, to avoid inflationary financing. Furthermore, to avoid the inflationary experience o f 2002-03 and ensure that spending remains in line with assured fimding, the government has identified contingent expenditures to be reduced in the event that additional grants are not mobilized. To ensure consistency with sustainable government finances and extemal debt, the government i s committed to remaining prudent in taking on new commitments. Government may also need to re-phase expenditures to the second halfo f the year (as it didin2004), ifuncertainties ingrant financing continue to be an issue.
8. Monetary and exchange rate policy. The growth rate for broadmoney slowed from 15 percent at end-December 2003 to 6.9 percent in May 2004. This slow down was a result o f a decline inprivate sector demand for credit. While net foreign exchange inflows were higher than expected, they were offset by movements in other items in bank balance sheets. Given these events, coupled with a stronger than expected earnings on coffee and tin exports and the slow down o f import demand for industrial inputs and consumer goods, the Rwandan franc/US $ exchangerate stabilized during2004.  9. Banking and Financial Sector. The problem of non-performing loans persists. However, the recent completion o f sale for the Commercial Bank o f Rwanda (BCR) and the Continental Bank o f Rwanda (BACAR), at the beginning o f August 2004 should provide significant improvements inthe level o f soundness o f the sector- the two banks together have heldthe highest share o fnon-performing loans. The plannedrecapitalization o fthe Development Bank of Rwanda (BRD) should helpto hrther strengthenfinancial intermediation. An adequate regulatory and supervisory framework derived from a credible and focused strategy should form part o f the approach to improving the soundness o f the sector. In this regard, the upcoming Financial Sector Assessment will aid in the development o f a strategy and identification o f specific andmonitorable actions.
10. Bankingregulationand supervision was strengthenedwith anew set ofregulations at end o f 2003. Three new regulations raised the solvency ratio from 8 to 10 percent and improved the definition o f credit concentration and asset quality. Furthermore, there hasbeengreater prudence in the assessment of loan guarantees as an effort to improve loan recovery. However, loan recovery remains a lengthy process and continued reform i s needed, notably with respect to the judicial system. Steps have also been taken to improve regulation o f micro-finance and cooperative institutions.
11. Despite the improvements inregulation and supervision, there continues to be a problem with compliance with banking regulation. In order to improve compliance by banks on risk concentration limits, most banks have elaborated action plans to address the problem. However, the bank holding the second largest deposits, appears to be confronting exceptional problems and has consistently failed to comply with a large number o f bankingregulations. An actionplan for returning to regulatory compliance on its solvency ratio, risk concentration and limits, liquidity ratios and net foreign exchange positions has been recently agreed between BNR and BCR management and i s beingimplemented.As a result, the situationi s improving.
12. Balance of Payments and ExternalDebt. There appears to be a modest improvement in2004 to 19.6percent (compared to the earlier estimated level of 19.8 percent, in2004). Coffee export volumes appeared to have increased substantially, while international market prices have recovered from last year's lows, as a result o f poor harvest inBrazil. There was also an increase in the world market for tin which doubled the projected level o f exports. However, export performance inthe tea andnon-traditional export sectors remainweak.
13. External debt steadied in 2003. But, preliminary estimates indicate that the net present value (NPV) o f debt-to-exports rose to 315 percent as o f end-2003, after the enhanced HIPC Initiative relief. This deterioration in the NPV i s mainly due to the impact o f a change in the discount and exchange rates-more so than the weaker-than-expected export performance. However, the ratio i s projectedto increase to 340 percent in2004 givenprojectednew borrowing (US$ 45 million), and a year-on-year growth rate o f goods and services exports that exceeds 20 percent.
14. StructuralReforms. The government continues to adhere to its reforms program. The  - 4 -
Organic Budget Law was approved by the Cabinet in June 2004 and submitted to parliament in late-July 2004. The government has also initiated implementation o f financial instructions to support the new budget law; and has also begun the process to submit new tax and customs legislation, along with a revisedinvestmentcode, to parliamentfor consideration.
15. Inaddition, the Auditor General's 2002 report was submitted to parliament inFebruary 2004, and the 2003 report will be submitted in October 2004. There i s also the anticipated approval o f the Auditor General's Act which will add to this achievement. Looking forward, the proposed increased funding to local governments, and to the overall decentralization process will require improvement in financial administration, including establishment o f monthly reporting mechanisms. Furthermore, the government will soon introduce the SIBET 2 (end-2004)-an updated version o f the SIBET (the government's project finance and expenditure management software) which will incorporate all key departments in the Ministry o f Finance along with the sector ministries. Steps will also be taken to follow-up on the closing o f dormant government accounts, and publication o f monthly reconciliation accounts for government financial statements.
16. The privatization agenda has taken a major step forward with the privatization o f BCR and BACAR and the sale o f the Pfunda tea factory. Government had also reached the point of sale (see footnote 1, below) with Mulinditea factory. However, government could not reach an agreement on terms that it felt would benefit the sector and industry. As a result, the contract negotiations were terminated. A new schedule for the sale o f the factory has been established, and government i s moving ahead with the scheduled privatization o f the next set o f 4 tea factories. Actions to complete privatization o f the tea sector, and inparticular another tea factory prior to the HIPC decision point document should proceed promptly. Inaddition, government shares inRwandatel, Rwandex, and PrimeHoldings are scheduled to beprivatized quickly.
17. The authorities are also committed to civil service reform and are receiving technical assistance from DFID inthis regard. The Bank i s providing support to capacity buildingthrough the Public Sector Capacity Building Project. As the reform could have a substantial impact on the government's ability to implement its operations, a prudent course, in consultation with partnerswill needto bepursued.

ANNEX
Progressin Achieving Measures Specifiedinthe Letter of DevelopmentPolicy
1. Overall, progress in targets and policy measures contained inthe Letter o f Development Policy has been satisfactory. Progress has been made in various areas-trade and exchange regime, financial sector, agricultural policies, privatization, budget reform, and public administration reform. There have also been activities in the areas o f the legal environment for enhanced good governance, privatization o f public enterprises, budget and public administration reform, and financial restructuring andreform. A Comprehensive Action Planfor the Elimination o f all Discrimination Against Women (Legal Action Plan) has been prepared and approved by the Cabinet o f Ministers. This complements the anti-discrimination law passed inOctober 2001 by Rwanda's Transitional Assembly, which punishes "any act, utterance or writing aimed at depriving a person or group o f persons, their rights, by reason o f sex, ethnicity, age, race, color, opinion, religionnationalityor origin."
2. A summary ofprogress according to the main broad areas of the Letter of Development Policy are outlined below: i)Public Expenditure Management; ii)Public Service Reform; iii) Agriculture and Rural Development; iv) HumanResource Development/Social Sector Reform; and v) Private Sector Development and Employment Creation.
1. PublicExpenditureManagement
3. The policy o f protecting social sector budget allocations from cuts during the course o f the fiscal year, adopted in 1999,has continuedto be followed. Inaddition, military expenditures have progressively been reduced to release resources for priority development programs. As mentioned above an important change that has occurred pertains to budget presentation. Since the 2002 budget cycle, all expenditures have been classified according to programs and sub- programs, expected outputs, activities and inputs, inall ministries.
4. The sensitization o f stakeholders and the emphasis on training o f staff in core and line ministries has facilitated the introduction o f the MTEF. Districts are now receiving training in budget preparation using the MTEF approach. However, more work i s required in defining and linking spending ceilings to district development plans, to ensure appropriate costing, given the available resources.
5. Ingeneral, achievements inpublic expendituremanagement includeimprovements to the cash management system, computerizationo f the budget andbudgetreporting, the preparation o f an organic budget law, further strengtheningo f the Auditor General's Office, and the issuance o f guidelines for opening, closing, and monitoring government bank accounts. In 2002, the office o f Auditor General conducted audit missions o f 10 ministries, including defense, and 13 projects. Professional audit standards were set in place, and a new Auditor General Act was drafted. In addition, a new Division o f Public Accounts was set up in the Ministry o f Economic Planning  - 10-
and Finance to develop accounting structures and systems in line with the medium term expenditureframework (MTEF) andthe budget. 6. The next stage o f reforms (to be covered under the PRSC), will continue the implementation o f the FARAP, and the strengthening o f reporting and auditing mechanisms at district levels, with a focus on integrationo f the development budget and the recurrent budget.
2. Agriculture andRuralDevelopment
7. In general, the sector has experienced declining factor productivity as a result of inadequate investment and research into appropriate technology. The effects o f inadequate investment has been particularly apparent in the export crop sector. In addition, for the main export crops o f coffee and tea, declining international prices has provided an incentive for farmers to move into more high value, horticultural crops such as passion fruit. Coupled with these events, during the 2003 growing season, drought affected the level o f production, leadingto higher food prices and inflation. These events, coupled with high oil prices have also led to higherproductioncosts andtherefore lower returns to farmers.
8. Giventhe above factors, the government recognizes theneedto redouble effort inthis key area o f the PRSP to ensure improved productivity, and increased returns to farmers. To this end, the govemment's strategy is focused on: (i)intensification, through increased utilization of agricultural inputs and cultural practices, and improved research; (ii)diversification toward high value crops and non-traditional export crops, and measures to enhance competitiveness and quality o f Rwandan tea and coffee; (iii)improved natural resource management, which has increased in importance particularly following the genocide, and has led to complex sequences o f landoccupation and competing claims on land.
9. Proper resolution o f tenure disputes i s key to promoting long-term productive investments in agriculture. The draft landpolicy has already been debated by cabinet andwill be submitted to Parliament in 2004. In addition, the government will need to elaborate a master plan for land utilization and management with a focus on appropriate technologies and practices for naturalresources protectionand management. An environmentalagency has been established to elaborate policies for protecting the environment, limiting the effect o f weather shocks and improving sustainability. Finally, to improve opportunities for rural non-fann income generation, the government will need to provide the enabling environment for identification and diffusion o f existing potential in rural areas and empower communities with the resources and capacity building support, including cooperatives to diversify their income sources. The Bank i s supporting the government inthis effort through the Rural Support Credit, and the PRSC.
10. In the case of export led growth, the government is emphasizing improved exports for coffee and tea. An inter-ministerial Export Promotion Commission has been established, to be chaired by the Ministry o f Commerce. The action plan i s to take an integrated approach recognizing the importance o f addressing constraints all along the production, and marketing  - 11-
chain. The government will produce a technical assessment for the Integrated Framework for Trade; and the Bankwill support the government inthis process.
11. The nationalplans for coffee and tea foresee a four to five fold growthinexport revenues from these two sub-sectors by 2010. These are ambitious targets and much depends on world market conditions for coffee, how well the privatization o f the tea sub-sector proceeds, and how effectively government can implement the institutional and policy reforms necessary to increase production. However, even more modest growth inthese two industrieswill make a substantial improvement in aggregate and per hectare income to farmers and processing plant workers. There i s a similar degree o f optimism about potential income and employment increases from pyrethruminthe Ruhengeriarea.
12. Inaddition to the above measures, the recently launched HIM0 public works program will help address the pressingproblemof infrastructure development andrehabilitation, and non- farm rural employment and income generation. This intervention i s aimed at both building infrastructure inaddition to providing temporary employment, and non-farm income for the rural population. In the water and energy sectors, there i s a need to define key priority activities to improve access to services while also feeding into improved income generation. Inparticular, issues o f water supply for rural production, sanitation and water for health, and rural electrification, development o f alternative energy sources should be among the key components o f a comprehensive infrastructure strategy, and will form part o f the policy dialogue under the PRSC.
13. Other upcomingreforms will focus on institutionalizing an export promotion strategy and action plan, and establishing the corresponding institutional and regulatory framework. Specific reforms for each commodity will continue. In particular, reforms will continue with the privatization o f remaining tea factories, building on the lessons learned from privatization o f Mulindi and Pfunda tea factories. In addition, the role of OCIR-thC as regulator will be reassessedand tailored to the new policy environment.
3. HumanResourcesDevelopment/SocialSector Reform
14. The GoR has made great strides inthe educationsector interms o f improvedenrollment rates which are now estimated at 82%. Government has also decided on the following new policy measures: i)free primary education for first 9 years o f basic education; ii)trilingual language policy; iii)subsidy o f private schools to promote girls' education. There i s also the additional challenge to improve quality . Educationaccounts for 25% o f government's total current budget (net o f debt payment). Yet, there i s still a funding gap. The focus under the PRSC will be prioritize the areas for reform (with attention to increased quality), and the corresponding policy trade-offs, within the sector.
15. The healthsector is dynamic becauseo f the system o fwell developed NGOs anchored in grassroots activities, focused on co-financing with strong community involvement. There i s also  - 12-
a micro-insurance program that serves 500,000 beneficiaries. Progress has been made in reducing the incidence o f communicable diseases such as malaria and childhood diseases, and the percentage of births attended by qualified health personnel has increased by 3 percentage points. In the case o f HIV/AIDS, a multi-sectoral approach has been adopted. The main challenge remaining i s to address the issue o f why malaria i s still the number one cause o f morbidity and mortality. Even though community involvement and co-financing i s strong, there i s a need for increased resources to the health sector. The PRSC will also cover key reforms in the healthsector.
16. In the case of gender and budget related institutional issues, in the area of human development, a Gender Action Plan (2001-2005) was adopted by Cabinet in 2000, and i s currently under implementation. Inaddition, a Comprehensive Gender Action Plan to eliminate gender disparities in the law was also prepared, and adopted in 2003. Capacity building involving the Government and NGOs i s underway for the implementation o f the Legal Action Plan. Recent implementation activity has involved the assurance o f gender sensitive reforms o f the Constitution, the Landlaw and the anti-discrimination law adopted by the National Assembly inOctober 2001outlawingdiscriminationagainst anybody, "whether basedon ethnicity, color of the skin, physical features, origin, sex, opinions, religions"(Law No 47/200 1).
4. Private Sector Development and Employment Creation
17. Considerable progress has beenmade inprivate sector development (PSD) inthe form o f privatization and support to medium and small enterprises. Out o f 77 companies to be privatized 50 have already been sold. In addition, a center to cater to the development o f small and medium enterprises was restructured into a non-profit and i s now fully operational in 2003. There are also ongoing reforms and privatization in the tea sector. The current PSIA o f these reforms indicate the potential for high benefits to the sector provided key structural issues pertaining to farmers' access to credit and inputs (fertilizer, seeds, pesticides) are improved. The PSIA also suggests that the quality o f tea has declined as a result o f the change in OCIR-th6's role fiom one o f subsidizing input markes and marketing functions, to one o f regulator. To ensure the growth foreseen does occur, government will need to move quickly to redefine the role o f OCIR-th6 inits new capacity as regulator.
18. With the support o f the Bank, the Government prepared and adopted policies and strategies for the privatization of Rwandatel (the telephone monopoly), and the nine publicly owned tea factories. The legislation for the regulation o f the telecommunication sector was passed in 2001. A Multi-sector regulatory agency became operational in October 2002 and the call for bids for privatization o f Rwandatel has been launched. A planto restructure Electrogaz, the energy/water utility, has been adopted, and the private operator for Electrogaz was selected and has been inplace since October 2003.
19. Inthe financial and bankingsector, as of end September 2003, total loans outstanding had increased by 8.5% since year-end 2002, with non-performing loans (NPLs) at 29.9% o f the  - 13 -
total loan portfolio, down somewhat from earlier years. An inter-bank commission had previously looked into the NPLproblem duringthe second half of 2002, andhadmade a number o f concrete recommendations to deal with the existing problems to mitigate future portfolio problems. Although progress on these measures have been slow, a number o f measures were taken by the banks or Banque Nationale du Rwanda (BNR), which resulted in significant improvement inrecoveries. Inthe case of the Union Banque Populaire (a cooperative o f micro- finance institutions), non-performing loans have steadily decreased and stand now at 20% overall, with 13% at the group bank level and 66% at the Unionlevel. While these figures remain high, they represent a significant improvement over past levels. An additional step, recently undertaken by government was to initiate the development of a database on micro-finance borrowers, and the registrationof micro-finance institutions with the central bank.
20. The government has also made a commitment to privatize the commercialbank, Banque Commerciale Rwandaise (BCR), whose portfolio o f NPLs accounts for 25% o f all NPLs in the sector. GoR i s committed to a successful sale to a strong buyer that will not only improve operation of the bank, but also contribute toward strengthening the whole sector. Interested bidders have begun their due diligence, and the privatization o f BCR to be completed by end- June 2004.
5. ImprovingGovernance and Transparency
21. There has been significant progress inthe area o f political and economic governance. The constitution was capped by a referendum in May 2003. Parliamentary and presidential elections took place betweenAugust and October 2003, There i s an ongoing review o f all laws, and the crime rate has declined by 20% as a result o f community sensitization. Although somewhat behind schedule, good progress has been made in the area o f demobilization and re- integration into civilian life, o f forces from DRC. The unity and national reconciliation commission continues to progress with its work, while the human rights commission has already publishedits annual report, and has opened offices in all the major provinces. The next step, following adoption o f the new constitution i s to develop indicators for humanrights monitoring. Inline with this, new organigrams of civil servants in central government line ministries are being implemented. Roughly 509 members were redeployed to decentralized units o f government.
22. Existing institutions for donor harmonization and support will need to be strengthened for improved implementation o f the PRSP. Currently, the cluster thematic groups, whose objectives have been to facilitate the development and implementation o f sector strategies have played a major role in harmonization. These clusters are arranged around the main themes contained in the PRSP and meet on a regular basis, with the aim to harmonize donor support around government priorities. The rate o f progress has varied across clusters and sector themes. There has been significant progress in the education and HIV/AIDS cluster. In the case o f education, the existence o f a SWAP has played a major role in promoting participation and coordination among donors, in addition to providing a coherent vision o f the sector. 23. In terms of budget support, a Partnership Framework agreement was recently reached between key budget support donors and GoR. This agreement on budget support harmonization focuses on the key areas o f public financial management, macro economic policy and PRSP monitoring. This framework will form the basis for harmonizationo f budget support, ingeneral and in the context o f the upcoming PRSC. The main goals of the Framework are to ensure flexibility, reliability and timeliness o f budget support, and to streamline donor requirements while aligning support to the PRSP review andbudgetcycle.

doc.abstracts: The Institutional Reform Credit Project builds on the progress made in reforms under the preceding Economic Recovery Credit (ERC), and consolidates the benefits from those reforms. Despite de Government's continued commitments to reform, GDP growth remains at just under 3 percent per annum, a slow down that resulted from lower than expected agricultural output, and the current electricity shortage. The report outlines problems in public finance, and in the monetary policy, affecting the banking and financial sector. However, conditions for the release of the third tranche have been met, thus, in view of the overall performance and progress with the implementation of the program supported by the Credit, and in full compliance with the specific conditions of release in accordance to the Credit Agreement, availability of the third (floating) tranche is released.
